I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Poor governance and corruption deter investment, waste resources and distort their 
allocation, undermine the credibility of authorities, and increase insecurity. On 31 July 2006, the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the second Governance and Anticorruption Action 
Plan (GACAP II), which aims to improve ADB’s performance in implementing governance and 
anticorruption policies in sectors where ADB is active. At the same time, the Pacific Plan’s goal 
is  to  enhance  economic  growth,  sustainable  development,  good  governance,  and  security 
through regionalism. In October 2005, Pacific Island Forum (PIF) leaders, in consideration of 
substantial benefits accruing from regional cooperation,1 endorsed for further study and analysis 
Pacific Plan initiative 12.1, which includes the Pacific Regional Audit Initiative (PRAI).   
 
2.  This  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  the  design  of  the  PRAI  and  the  pilot 
implementation of GACAP II in Pacific developing member countries (DMCs) of ADB. The TA is 
consistent with the Pacific Strategy for the Asian Development Bank 2005-2009,2 which identifies 
as a key result area, strengthened government transparency and accountability. Moreover, in 
supporting the 2005 Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness,3 recipient countries have committed 
to publishing timely, transparent, and reliable (audited) financial reports, while development 
partners (including ADB) have, among other things, committed to relying to the maximum extent 
possible  on  country  public  financial  management  systems.4 The  TA  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  GACAP II reaffirmed the findings of an earlier review6 that identified the need for action in 
the following critical areas: (i) filling the significant gaps in compliance with the governance and 
anticorruption policies and relevant operations manuals and project administration instructions; 
(ii)  building  stronger  partnerships  with  multilateral  and  bilateral  development  institutions, 
particularly in accessing country diagnostics and strengthening countries’ procurement systems 
and public financial management; (iii) more effectively applying institutional knowledge and 
country and sector diagnostics to determine focus and priorities; and (iv) instituting more flexible, 
longer-term institutional development arrangements to address systemic weaknesses in sector 
governance and corruption. Implementing GACAP II will enable ADB’s DMCs in partnership with 
ADB,  and  with  civil  society  involvement,  to  design  and  deliver  better  quality  projects  and 
programs. 
 
4.  Effective  public  auditing  underpins  good  governance  and  accountability.  In  that 
connection, regionalism is not new to Pacific public auditors⎯they are represented by the South 
Pacific Association of Supreme Audit Institutions (SPASAI),7 which is a regional working group

organizations and institutions in other parts of the world, promoting closer collaboration and brotherhood among

2   
of the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI).8 In December 2005, 
the PIF Secretariat (PIFS) agreed that ADB would work in coordination with PIFS to move the 
PRAI forward. ADB consulted with SPASAI and its member supreme audit institutions (SAIs) to 
develop  awareness  of  and  seek  support  for  the  PRAI. 9  The  2006  SPASAI  Congress 
subsequently agreed in principle to the PRAI.  
 
5.  An SAI exists in each Pacific jurisdiction (Appendix 2). But the effectiveness of Pacific 
SAIs is generally limited by their ability to attract, retain, and develop qualified staff due to their 
small sizes and remote locations, difficulties in competing with the private sector for qualified 
staff, often-constrained budgets, and limited access to professional accounting bodies. However, 
there is a range of capacities, with some Pacific SAIs meeting best practice in many respects. 
Moreover,  SPASAI  membership  is  diverse  with  members  from  developed  and  developing 
countries; British, French, and United States (US)-influenced systems; and varying regional 
memberships.  
 
6.  ADB has provided four TA grants to SPASAI since 1989, some of which were supported 
jointly by the INTOSAI Development Initiative (IDI).10 A 2002 review of efforts to strengthen 
Pacific audit capability concluded that intended benefits were achieved but much more remained 
to be done.11 Lessons learned included the need to thoroughly diagnose requirements, address 
legal independence and mandate issues, and address accounts-preparation issues. To provide 
contextual information, SPASAI prepared a membership stocktaking in May 2006, which identified 
the following issues. 
 
7.  Audit  Scope,  Quality,  and  Timeliness.  Most  Pacific  SAIs  conduct  financial  and 
performance audits, but only the Cook Islands, Fiji, and Palau undertake environmental audits. 
Financial audit quality varies significantly and capacity constraints mean that several SAIs are 
unable to meet their audit obligations. Meanwhile, several SAIs have audit backlogs due to 
limited capacity and or nonprovision of financial reports for audit. One SAI has arrears of 9 years 
and several are in arrears by 3–4 years. Nevertheless, SAIs have made sound progress in 
clearing outstanding backlogs in recent years and continued efforts are planned. 
 
8.  Accounting and Auditing Standards. Financial reporting and auditing standards vary 
across jurisdictions. For instance, US-affiliated jurisdictions are mandated to follow generally 
accepted government auditing standards (GAGAS or the Yellow Book), while others have their 
own standards or intend to harmonize with international benchmarks. Most SAIs are challenged 
by the introduction of new and emerging standards. 
 
9.  Professional Qualifications and Training. The prevalence varies, but few SAIs have 
suitable  levels  of  professionally  qualified  staff.  US-affiliated  jurisdictions  rely  on  the  US 
professional system, but among other SPASAI members, only three⎯Fiji, Samoa, and Papua 
                                                                                                                                                           
auditors in the government service among regional groups, assisting each other by providing technical assistance, 
and exchanging of expertise that will benefit members.  
8  INTOSAI, established in 1953, is the professional organization of SAIs in countries that belong to the United 
Nations or its specialized agencies. 
9  Consultations included discussions with SPASAI members, PIFS, and development partners at conferences and 
workshops in Suva, Fiji (26 February–3 March 2006); Port Moresby (January–April 2006); Nadi, Fiji (6–7 April 
2006); and Saipan, Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (18–26 May 2006). 
10  IDI was established in 1986 as INTOSAI’s training arm. Its mission is to help SAIs, especially in developing 
countries, to improve their audit capacity and resolve audit issues through training and information sharing. 
11  ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance Performance Audit Report on Strengthening Audit Capability in the Pacific. Manila 
(October).

3
New Guinea (PNG)⎯have local professional accounting bodies.12 This makes it difficult for staff 
to  attain  professional  qualifications.  Ongoing  professional  development  and  staff  training  is 
critical to enable SAIs to deliver their mandates⎯most training is provided by SPASAI through 
IDI and by the Association of Pacific Island Public Auditors (APIPA) through the Pacific Islands 
Training Initiative (PITI). The quality of training provided is considered high, but follow-up and 
monitoring could be improved. 
 
10.  Resources and Technical Support. For some SAIs, resources are limited compared to 
mandated activities. While generally low, staff turnover is high in those SAIs such as Cook 
Islands,  Fiji,  and  Samoa  that  have  managed  to  professionalize.  The  departure  of  most 
professionally  qualified  staff  is  for  external  opportunities  and  further  studies  overseas.  A 
competent  technical  support  function  is  essential  to  effective  auditing,  but  SAIs  lack  the 
economies of scale that are necessary to establish and operate such a function on a sustainable 
basis. 
 
11.  Kiribati,  Nauru,  and  Tuvalu  have  indicated  to  ADB  and  the  Australian  Agency  for 
International Development (AusAID) their interest in investigating design options for a subregional 
approach to public auditing.  
 
12.  The  issues  identified  are  broad  in  scope  and  vary  across  the  region.  SPASAI  has 
effectively managed audit training and networking options, but with its very limited resources has 
been unable to address other issues—the PRAI development provides an opportunity to do so. 
To that end SPASAI identified certain key PRAI design considerations: (i) SAI autonomy and 
independence must be preserved; (ii) a regional approach is appropriate for addressing common 
issues, but SPASAI members will continue to have individual needs; and (iii) the PRAI should 
apply to all SPASAI members, not just to PIF or ADB members. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The  proposed  project  is  intended  to  promote  good  governance  through  improved 
transparency,  accountability,  and  efficiency  in  managing  and  using  public  resources  in  the 
Pacific.13 Specifically, the project is intended to strengthen the governance and anticorruption 
orientation of country partnership strategies (CPSs) and ADB projects and TAs in the Pacific. It 
is also intended to provide a basis for raising public auditing to uniformly high standards across 
the  Pacific  region,  beginning  with  the  diagnosis  of  SAI  and  region-wide  issues  and  the 
subsequent development of the PRAI design and road map, which will be considered at the 
2007 SPASAI Congress. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  Governance Component. Assessing public financial management, procurement, and 
corruption risks is an important starting point for formulating DMC development plans and CPSs. 
Drawing on assessment methodologies and tools that ADB is developing, and with civil society 
input,  the  component  will  support  the  preparation  and  implementation  of  governance, 
institutional, and corruption risk assessments and risk management plans at the country, sector, 
                                                 
12 The  predominant  professional  bodies  in  the  Pacific  region  are  the  American  Institute  of  Certified  Public 
Accountants, CPA Australia, the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia, and the New Zealand Institute of 
Chartered Accountants. 
13  Pacific Plan, initiative 12.

4   
and project levels. It will also support training for government officials, project staff, and civil 
society organizations on the application of relevant ADB policies and guidelines.14 
 
15.  PRAI  Component.  Expected  TA  outputs  comprise:  (i)  identifying  the  good-practice 
features of an SAI, including mandate, independence, management policies and procedures, 
audit  procedures  and  methodologies,  auditing  standards,  and  resources;  (ii)  identifying  the 
status  of  20  individual  SAIs,15 including  consideration  of  the  public  financial  management 
environment, the status of private sector auditing, and the mechanisms by which the legislature 
and the public scrutinize audit findings, including an analysis of civil society engagement; (iii) 
analyzing  regionwide  issues  including  education  and  training,  professional  qualifications, 
independence,  financial  auditing,  performance  auditing,  standards,  information  technology 
options,  and  institutional  arrangements⎯the  diagnosis  will  identify  factors  that  facilitate 
successful  SAI  transformations;  (iv)  analyzing  opportunities  and  presenting  options  for 
establishing a subregional approach to public auditing for Kiribati, Nauru, and Tuvalu; and (v) 
developing an agreed upon PRAI design and road map that addresses SPASAI institutional 
arrangements and does not weaken existing private sector auditing. The PRAI design and road 
map will also identify PRAI’s intermediate and long-term goals, identify issues that must be 
addressed to reach those goals, and present a road map for reaching them (including resource 
and structural implications, and monitoring and evaluation indicators).16 To accomplish these 
objectives, activities will be undertaken in three phases.17 
 
16.  Phase 1: Identify Benchmarks. SAI good practice features will be identified and a 
diagnostic design and plan⎯including a detailed questionnaire⎯will be prepared. These will be 
reviewed and confirmed by the SPASAI Regional Institutional Strengthening Committee (RISC). 
 
17.  Phase  2:  Diagnosis.  Using  identified  SAI  benchmarks,  diagnostic  studies  will  be 
prepared for 20 SPASAI members. It is envisaged that this will require field visits to most of 
these SAIs, beginning with Fiji. A regionwide diagnosis of issues will also be undertaken and will 
include identifying factors that facilitate successful SAI transformations. A RISC workshop will 
review progress and provide guidance on the preliminary diagnostic work, beginning with the 
draft Fiji diagnostic report. It is envisaged that this first 3-day RISC workshop will be convened in 
Suva, Fiji, in February 2007.18 
 
18.  Phase 3: Road Map and Subregional Design Options. The PRAI design and road 
map  will  be  developed  on  the  basis  of  the  diagnostic  work  and  RISC  consultations.  The 
diagnostic  work  will  also  provide  a  basis  for  identifying  design  options  for  establishing  a 
subregional approach to public auditing for Kiribati, Nauru, and Tuvalu. A second 5-day RISC 
workshop in August 2007 will review the completed diagnostic work and consider preliminary 
proposals for the PRAI design and road map.19 The workshop will also review the proposed

subregional design options, which will be finalized subsequently. The revised PRAI design and 
road map will be presented in October 2007 for consideration and endorsement by the 2007

C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA’s total cost is estimated at $1,979,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan ($982,500) and by 
the Government of Australia ($596,500). ADB will administer these funds. Government share of 
the  cost  will  comprise  $400,000  and  will  involve  in-kind  contributions  from  participating 
governments (Appendix 3).  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ADB will be the Executing Agency (EA) for the governance component and the SPASAI 
Secretariat will be the EA for the PRAI component.20 The RISC will provide oversight and 
guidance to the SPASAI Secretariat (in a steering committee-type role). 
 
21.  The governance component will require international consultants (9 person-months) and 
national consultants (10 person-months) with governance, financial management, procurement, 
and anticorruption skills. Given the intermittent need and multiple skills required, consultants for 
this component will be engaged as individuals.  
 
22.  PRAI phase 1 activities will be undertaken by an individual public auditing expert (1.5 
person-months of international consulting services), who will prepare a report identifying SAI 
good-practice features. PRAI phase 2 and 3 activities will be undertaken by a consulting firm, 
which will supply 31 person-months of international consulting services. It is highly desirable that 
the  firm  demonstrates  previous  successful  experience  working  in  the  Pacific  Islands  on 
regionwide projects; ideally in both US- and non-US-influenced countries. The firm will provide 
experts in public auditing, education and professional qualifications, information technology, and 
legal matters. The consultants will organize RISC workshops in February 2007 and August 2007 
to review progress and provide guidance. The consultants will also organize a workshop at the 
2007 SPASAI Congress at which the PRAI will be presented. Appendix 4 details deliverables 
and reporting requirements. The quality- and cost-based selection procedure will be followed to 
select the consulting firm. Short-listed firms will submit full technical proposals. 
 
23.  All consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (April 2006). Outline terms of reference for consulting services are in Appendix 4. 
TA activities will be implemented over a 36-month period starting in December 2006. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of the technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $596,500 to 
be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Australia, and (ii) ADB providing the balance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $982,500 to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special 
Fund, funded by the Government of Japan, for Strengthening Governance and Accountability in 
Pacific Island Countries. 
                                                 
20  The Office of the Controller and Auditor General of New Zealand currently performs the SPASAI Secretariat 
function on a voluntary basis.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Governance Component 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will provide approximately 9 person-months of intermittent 
international and 10 person-months of intermittent national consulting services with a focus on 
financial management, procurement, and anticorruption expertise. Specific sector and regional 
expertise will be highly desirable. Specific consulting requirements will be refined further based on 
the country partnership strategies (CPSs), sectors, and projects selected for implementation. 
 
2.  The consultants will undertake the following activities: (i) support the Pacific Department 
(PARD) country teams in consultations with development partners, civil society, and the Regional 
and Sustainable Development Department to assess the depth and quality of existing governance 
and anticorruption diagnostics at the national, subnational, sector, and project level; (ii) together 
with developing member country (DMC) officials, development partners, civil society and PARD 
country teams, undertake financial management, procurement, and corruption risk assessments; 
(iii) together with DMC officials and in consultation with civil society and the PARD country team, 
develop risk mitigating strategies at the national, subnational, sector, and project level; (iv) provide 
relevant  input  into  CPS  documents;  (v)  design  approaches  for  implementing  risk  mitigating 
strategies; and (vi) train government officials, civil society organizations, and project managers on 
risk assessment and management approaches, and on the practical application of relevant ADB 
policies and guidelines, including governance and financial management. 
 
B.  Pacific Regional Audit Initiative Component 
1.  Phase 1 Activities: Public Auditing Expert (international, 1.5 person-months) 
3.  An individual public auditing expert will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (April  2006).  The  expert  will  have  a  professional  accountancy 
qualification and at least 10 years of relevant experience. Public auditing experience in the Pacific 
islands is highly desirable. 
 
4.  The  expert,  under  the  guidance  and  supervision  of  the  South  Pacific  Association  of 
Supreme  Audit  Institutions  (SPASAI)  secretariat  and  the  SPASAI  Regional  Institutional 
Strengthening Committee (RISC), will prepare a report that identifies the good-practice features 
expected of a well-functioning SAI including mandate, independence, management policies and 
procedures, audit procedures and methodologies, auditing standards, and resources. As part of 
the  report,  the  consultant  will  prepare  a  comprehensive  questionnaire  and  accompanying 
instructions, which will be distributed to SPASAI members to facilitate the subsequent diagnostic 
work. The diagnostic approach is expected to use relevant performance indicators from the Public 
Expenditure  and  Financial  Accountability  (PEFA)  public  financial  management  performance 
measurement framework.1 
 
2.  Phase 2 and 3 Activities: Consulting Firm 
5.  Previous  successful  experience  working  in  the  Pacific  Islands  on  regionwide  projects, 
ideally in both US- and non-US-influenced countries, is highly desirable. The firm must be able to 
                                                 
1 The relevant performance indicators (PI) are likely to be PI-10 (public access to key fiscal information); PI-25 (quality 
and timeliness of annual financial statements); PI-26 (scope, nature and follow-up of external audit); and PI-28 
(legislative scrutiny of external audit reports).

12  Appendix 4 
 
demonstrate its flexibility in collaborative work on a range of complex issues across a diverse 
group of countries. It is expected that the team leader and the public auditing expert will have 
between  them  an  extensive  knowledge  of  both  US-  and  non-US-influenced  public  auditing 
environments.  The  SPASAI  secretariat  function  is  provided  on  a  voluntary  basis  with  limited 
resources.  Consequently,  the  consulting  firm  should  consider  carefully  how  it  will  minimize 
administrative burdens for the secretariat during TA implementation. 
 
6.  Before the start of services, the firm will prepare a detailed work plan that will include a 
timetable for deliverables defined for each TA component. The consultants will submit interim 
reports within the deadline specified in the work plan agreed upon with the SPASAI Secretariat, 
Pacific Islands Forum Secretariat (PIFS), Asian Development Bank (ADB), and Australian Agency 
for International Development (AusAID). Interim reports will be reviewed by the SPASAI Secretariat, 
RISC, PIFS, ADB, and AusAID. Draft final reports will be submitted within the deadline specified in 
the work plans after incorporating feedback from SPASAI Secretariat, RISC, PIFS, ADB, and 
AusAID.  
 
a.  Team Leader / Public Auditing Expert (international, 10 person-months) 
7.  The  team  leader  will  have  significant  public  auditing  experience  in  a  senior  SAI 
management role, ideally in a change environment. Demonstrated experience in strategic planning 
is essential and experience in the Pacific is highly desirable. The team leader will undertake the 
following tasks. 
 
8.  Overall Leadership and Management. The team leader will coordinate the work of all 
consulting team members, in close collaboration with the SPASAI secretariat and RISC members. 
More specifically the team leader will: (i) prepare and distribute brief weekly updates and more 
detailed  monthly  work  plan  updates  to  the  SPASAI  Secretariat,  RISC  members,  and  other 
stakeholders; (ii) ensure that the TA is implemented according to the work plan and terms of 
reference agreed upon with the SPASAI Secretariat and RISC, and with the consultancy contract 
provisions;  (iii)  incorporate  any  subsequent  instructions  and  guidance  agreed  upon  with  the 
SPASAI Secretariat and RISC; (iv) collaborate closely with SPASAI Secretariat, RISC members, 
and  other  consultants; (v)  ensure  the  timely  preparation  of  all  required  reports⎯including an 
inception report, a midterm report, a draft final report, and a final report⎯in a format satisfactory to 
the  SPASAI  Secretariat  and  ADB;  (vi)  coordinate  the  organization  of  the  RISC  and  SPASAI 
workshops; and (vii) take responsibility for the collective work of the consulting team, and for 
coordinating and liaising with stakeholders, including SPASAI members, PIFS, ADB, and other TA 
cofinanciers. 
 
9.  Technical Activities. The team leader will: (i) review and, if necessary, suggest revisions 
to  the  good-practice  features  expected  of  a  well-functioning  SAI  and  the  accompanying 
questionnaire; (ii) together with the other public auditing expert, prepare the draft Fiji SAI diagnostic 
study for consideration by the RISC workshop; (iii) organize and facilitate the Fiji RISC workshop; 
(iv) prepare nine other SAI diagnostic studies; (v) coordinate and provide input to the preparation of 
the regionwide issues diagnosis; (vi) coordinate and provide input to the report that analyzes 
opportunities  and  presents  design  options  for  establishing  a  subregional  approach  to  public 
auditing for Kiribati, Nauru, and Tuvalu; (vii) prepare a report that considers regional experiences 
and identifies the factors that facilitate successful SAI transformations; (viii) organize and facilitate 
the second RISC workshop; (ix) identify SPASAI institutional options; (x) lead the preparation of 
the PRAI design and road map; and (xi) organize and facilitate the SPASAI workshop.

Appendix 4  13 
b.  Public Auditing Expert (international, 10 person-months) 
10.  The  public  auditing  expert  will  have  recent,  practical,  public  auditing  experience  in  a 
management role. Experience in the Pacific is highly desirable. The expert should be familiar with 
SAI  mandates,  independence,  management  policies  and  procedures,  audit  procedures  and 
methodologies, auditing standards, and institutional arrangements. 
 
11.  The expert will undertake the following tasks: (i) together with the team leader, prepare the 
draft Fiji SAI diagnostic study for consideration by the RISC workshop; (ii) facilitate the Fiji RISC 
workshop; (iii) prepare 10 other SAI diagnostic studies; (iv) provide input to the preparation of the 
regionwide issues diagnosis; (v) provide input to the analysis and design of options for establishing 
a subregional approach to public auditing for Kiribati, Nauru, and Tuvalu; (vi) facilitate the second 
RISC workshop; (vii) assist in preparing the PRAI design and road map; and (viii) facilitate the 
SPASAI workshop. 
 
c.  Education and Professional Qualification Expert (international, 6 person-
months) 
12.  The  education  and  professional  qualification  expert  will  have  theoretical  and  practical 
knowledge  of  professional  accounting  education  and  qualification  systems,  secondment  and 
twinning arrangements, and be familiar with the application of best-practice training approaches. 
The expert will be conversant with the promulgations of the International Accounting Education 
Standards Board (IAESB) and the professional requirements of the US Uniform Accountancy Act 
and  the  US  Government  Accountability  Office.  Direct  knowledge  of  more  than  one  of  the 
professional accountancy bodies active in the Pacific is desirable, as is knowledge of performance 
auditing and the requisite associated skills. The expert will undertake the following tasks. 
 
13.  The expert will prepare a regionwide diagnostic report that among other things: (i) identifies 
relevant education and professional qualification benchmarks; (ii) identifies and compares regional 
educational and professional qualifications against those benchmarks; (iii) reviews relevant training 
courses, the methodologies employed and their effectiveness; (iv) analyzes the educational and 
professional backgrounds of SAI personnel and their match with duties undertaken—for instance, 
an engineering rather than an accountancy qualification may be more appropriate for conducting 
certain  performance  audits;  (v)  identifies  and  considers  previous  regional  experiences  with 
secondments and twinning arrangements; and (vi) identifies and presents for RISC review and 
consideration,  concrete  options  for  strengthening  SAI  personnel  competencies  (including 
associated benefits, costs, risks and assumptions). 
 
14.  The expert will contribute to the PRAI design and road map. The RISC will identify the 
preferred options from the diagnostic report. The expert will refine these options and present a 
road map moving forward with early wins clearly identified, and with options prioritized in terms of 
benefits, but also cognizant of time taken to overcome major constraints. 
 
d.  Information Technology Expert (international, 2 person-months) 
15.  The  information  technology  expert  will  have  hands-on  financial  auditing  experience, 
including use of audit support software. In addition, the expert will have broad experience in 
selecting and implementing audit support software. Experience in a developing country is highly 
desirable. 
 
16.  The expert will undertake the following tasks: (i) prepare a report that, among other things, 
identifies  the  status  of  SAI  audit  automation,  identifies  the  prerequisites  for  introducing  audit

14  Appendix 4 
 
support software, and identifies and compares available software packages; and (ii) contribute to 
the PRAI design and road map, which will involve identifying, for RISC review and consideration, 
concrete options for introducing automated audit support to SAIs (including associated benefits, 
costs, risks and assumptions). 
 
e.  Legal Expert (international, 3 person-months) 
17.  The expert will have a professional legal qualification. Knowledge of both US- and non-US 
legal systems is desirable. Experience with the establishment of international nongovernment 
bodies will be highly desirable, as is experience in the Pacific region. 
 
18.  The expert will undertake the following tasks: (i) support, guide, and provide input to the 
other consultants’ work to assess SAI mandates against best-practice independence arrangements;  
(ii) identify potential legal issues and options regarding SPASAI’s possible future status as a 
regional body; and (iii) based on consultations and identified institutional preferences, identify the 
legal steps required for SPASAI to achieve the identified legal status.
